title: The moon illusion - Andrew Vanden Heuvel

multiple-choice.question: What is one explanation for the moon illusion, where the full moon appears bigger near the horizon than when it's high over head?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets.

options.label: B
options.text: The Ebbinghaus Illusion, where two identical objects look different because of the relative size of the objects they're surrounded by.

options.label: C
options.text: The Ponzo Illusion, where our brain compensates automatically for the distance of objects near the horizon.

options.label: D
options.text: The refraction of the atmosphere makes the moon look slightly smaller.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the moon illusion disappear if you bend over and look at the moon between your legs?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain's autocorrecting the size of objects near the horizon doesn't work when looking at the moon between your legs.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the focus of your eyes changes when looking at the moon between your legs.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the moon is not visible when looking at it between your legs.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Convergence Micropsia theory, why does the moon appear smaller when it's overhead?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brain thinks the moon is much farther away than it really is.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain thinks the moon is much closer than it really is.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere acts like a giant lens, magnifying the moon as it rises and sets.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the refraction of the atmosphere makes the moon look slightly smaller.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a detail that complicates the explanation of the moon illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Pilots and sailors out on the ocean still claim to see the moon illusion.

options.label: B
options.text: The moon illusion disappears entirely if you just bend over and look at the moon between your legs.

options.label: C
options.text: The Ebbinghaus effect is not visible inside a planetarium.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most promising explanations today for the moon illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ponzo Illusion.

options.label: B
options.text: The Ebbinghaus Illusion.

options.label: C
options.text: Convergence Micropsia.

options.label: D
options.text: The refraction of the atmosphere.

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A confusion of the past with the present

options.label: D
options.text: A misfiring of neurons in the brain

title: Should you trust your first impression? - Peter Mende-Siedlecki

multiple-choice.question: According to research in social psychology, we tend to form lasting impressions of others based on their behaviors, inferring stable character traits from a single behavior, such as a harsh word or a clumsy step. What is the primary reason for this tendency?

options.label: B
options.text: We are quick to form impressions due to a lack of effort.

options.label: C
options.text: We infer stable character traits from a single behavior because it is a reliable indicator of a person's true character.

options.label: D
options.text: We are influenced by cultural and social norms.

options.label: B
options.text: Immoral behaviors are more diagnostic of a person's true character.

options.label: C
options.text: Positive information is more easily forgotten than negative information.

options.label: D
options.text: We are naturally inclined to be pessimistic about others.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Negative information

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Information about a person's frequency of behavior

options.label: B
options.text: Areas typically associated with emotional regulation and memory

options.label: C
options.text: Areas typically associated with sensory perception and motor control

options.label: D
options.text: Areas typically associated with language processing and executive function

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why our brain might care more about the very negative, immoral things another person has done compared to the very positive, moral things?

options.label: A
options.text: Because immoral behaviors are more diagnostic of a person's true character.

options.label: B
options.text: Because good behaviors are more plentiful and therefore less impactful.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we are naturally inclined to be pessimistic about others.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are influenced by cultural and social norms.

options.label: B

options.text: The need for order and structure in the world.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a way to assert our dominance over others.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is a social convention that varies from culture to culture.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a form of entertainment that is solely based on physical humor.

title: What is chemical equilibrium? - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two molecules collide with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They just bounce off each other and that's it.

options.label: B
options.text: One molecule can join and become one with another molecule.

options.label: C
options.text: They can switch parts and become different molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: They can split apart and become two separate molecules.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two conditions that must be met for a chemical reaction to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: The molecules must be moving at a high speed and the temperature must be high.

options.label: B
options.text: The molecules must hit each other in the right orientation and with enough energy.

options.label: C
options.text: The molecules must be in a vacuum and the temperature must be low.

options.label: D
options.text: The molecules must be in a gas state and the pressure must be high.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the state where the number of molecules in each state stops changing, even though molecules are still colliding and exchanging parts?

options.label: A
options.text: Equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: Nirvana equilibrium

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular collision

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the distribution of molecules in a system that is in equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: Molecular distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Population distribution

options.label: D
options.text: Equilibrium distribution

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a system that shows the same pattern as chemical reactions in equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Gene pools

options.label: B
options.text: Highway traffic

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

title: A brief history of plural word...s - John McWhorter

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the differences between Modern English and Old English?

options.label: A
options.text: Modern English has a more complex grammar system.

options.label: B
options.text: Old English was spoken by fewer people than Modern English.

options.label: C
options.text: Modern English has a simpler grammar system than Old English.

options.label: D
options.text: Modern English has a more standardized vocabulary.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Vikings have a significant impact on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: They introduced new words and phrases into the language.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a way of smoothing away the harder parts of how English worked.

options.label: C
options.text: They were skilled linguists who helped to standardize the language.

options.label: D
options.text: They were responsible for the invention of the English alphabet.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the changes that the Vikings made to the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: They introduced the use of the letter "q".

options.label: B
options.text: They changed the way that plurals were formed.

options.label: C
options.text: They replaced the word "house" with "housen".

options.label: D
options.text: They changed the way that verbs were conjugated.

multiple-choice.question: Why didn't the English speakers use the plural form "gat" instead of "goats"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too difficult to pronounce.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was not widely used in the language.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the Vikings preferred the "s" form.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was not considered grammatically correct.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Vikings' influence on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: The language became more complex and difficult to learn.

options.label: B
options.text: The language became more standardized and easier to learn.

options.label: C
options.text: The language changed in a way that made it more similar to other languages.

options.label: D
options.text: The language remained unchanged.

title: What is dyslexia? - Kelli Sandman-Hurley

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of dyslexia?

options.label: A
options.text: A visual processing problem, where people see letters and words backwards.

options.label: B
options.text: A phonological processing problem, where people have trouble manipulating language.

options.label: C
options.text: A spatial processing problem, where people have trouble with shapes and patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: A memory problem, where people have trouble remembering words and phrases.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of people may be affected by dyslexia?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 1 in 10 people

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 1 in 5 people

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 1 in 20 people

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 1 in 50 people

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea that the brain is divided into two hemispheres, with the left hemisphere handling language and the right hemisphere handling spatial activities?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroplasticity

options.label: B
options.text: Neurodiversity

options.label: C
options.text: The Continuum Principle

options.label: D
options.text: The Hemispheric Theory

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the intervention that can help improve reading skills in people with dyslexia?

options.label: A
options.text: The Dyslexia Intervention Program

options.label: B
options.text: The Multi-Sensory Reading Program

options.label: C
options.text: The Syllable-Based Reading Program

options.label: D
options.text: The Intensive, Multi-Sensory Intervention

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that emphasizes the spectrum of brain function in all humans and suggests that we should try to understand the perspectives of those around us through their brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Neuroplasticity

options.label: B
options.text: Neurodiversity

options.label: C
options.text: The Continuum Principle

options.label: D
options.text: The Hemispheric Theory

title: The infinite life of pi - Reynaldo Lopes

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a circle's circumference and its diameter?

options.label: A
options.text: The circumference is always smaller than the diameter.

options.label: B
options.text: The circumference is always larger than the diameter.

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio of the circumference to the diameter is always the same number, no matter how big or small the circle gets.

options.label: D
options.text: The circumference and diameter are always equal.

multiple-choice.question: What is pi, and how is it used in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Pi is a ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, and it is used in building the Egyptian pyramids.

options.label: B
options.text: Pi is a ratio of a circle's area to its diameter, and it is used in calculating the volume of a can of soda.

options.label: C
options.text: Pi is a ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, and it is used in various scientific calculations involving circles, curves, and statistics.

options.label: D
options.text: Pi is a ratio of a circle's area to its circumference, and it is used in calculating the speed of computers.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about pi, and why is it used instead of its decimal form?

options.label: A
options.text: Pi is a whole number that can be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: Pi is an irrational number that can be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: Pi is an irrational number that can never be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers, and it is used instead of its decimal form because it is easier to write.

options.label: D
options.text: Pi is a decimal number that can be expressed as a ratio of two whole numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the scientific uses of pi?

options.label: A
options.text: Calculating the speed of computers and the orbits of satellites.

options.label: B
options.text: Calculating the volume of a can of soda and the orbits of planets.

options.label: C
options.text: Calculating the area under a normal distribution curve, studying curves, and understanding periodic or oscillating systems.

options.label: D
options.text: Calculating the density of our entire universe and the total number of digits in pi.

multiple-choice.question: What is a notable achievement of scientists using pi in particle physics experiments?

options.label: A
options.text: They were able to calculate the total number of digits in pi.

options.label: B
options.text: They were able to prove that light functions as a particle and an electromagnetic wave.

options.label: C
options.text: They were able to calculate the density of our entire universe.

options.label: D
options.text: They were able to build the Egyptian pyramids.

title: Comma story - Terisa Folaron

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the acronym that helps remember the conjunctions?

options.label: A
options.text: FAN

options.label: B
options.text: FANBOYS

options.label: C
options.text: COMMA

options.label: D
options.text: SENTENCE

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between subordinates and conjunctions in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: Subordinates are words that connect clauses, while conjunctions are words that connect words and phrases.

options.label: B
options.text: Subordinates are words that connect words and phrases, while conjunctions are words that connect clauses.

options.label: C
options.text: Subordinates are the WWE heavyweight champions of sentences, while conjunctions are small and nimble.

options.label: D
options.text: Subordinates are small and nimble, while conjunctions are the WWE heavyweight champions of sentences.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the role of a comma when a subordinate begins a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: The comma places itself directly after the first thought or complete sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: The comma places itself directly before the first thought or complete sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: The comma places itself directly after the subordinate.

options.label: D
options.text: The comma places itself directly before the conjunction.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why do conjunctions not need the help of a comma in certain situations?

options.label: A
options.text: Because conjunctions are small and nimble.

options.label: B
options.text: Because conjunctions are courteous creatures.

options.label: C
options.text: Because conjunctions can do a lot of heavy lifting by themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: Because conjunctions are not as militant as subordinates.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the law of physics that helps explain why commas are necessary in certain situations?

options.label: A
options.text: The law of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: The law of motion.

options.label: C
options.text: The law of physics that states that it's easier to balance heavy objects if the weight is evenly distributed.

options.label: D
options.text: The law of thermodynamics.

title: What is an aurora? - Michael Molina

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of the northern and southern lights (aurora Borealis and aurora Australis)?

options.label: A
options.text: High energy particles from the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: High energy particles from the Sun's corona

options.label: C
options.text: Low energy particles from the Earth's magnetic fields

options.label: D
options.text: Low energy particles from the Sun's surface

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Earth's magnetosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: To contain the solar wind and prevent it from reaching the atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: To send out particles around the Earth and shield the planet from the solar wind

options.label: C
options.text: To attract the solar wind and bring it closer to the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: To repel the solar wind and push it away from the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is a coronal mass ejection?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive ball of plasma shot out by the Earth's magnetic field

options.label: B
options.text: A massive ball of plasma shot out by the Sun's corona

options.label: C
options.text: A massive ball of plasma that collides with the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: A massive ball of plasma that is absorbed by the Earth's magnetic field

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the magnetosphere is overwhelmed by a coronal mass ejection?

options.label: A
options.text: The particles are sent back to the Sun

options.label: B
options.text: The particles are absorbed by the Earth's magnetic field

options.label: C
options.text: The particles are flung towards the Earth and create a magnetic storm

options.label: D
options.text: The particles are neutralized by the Earth's atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the interaction between the Sun's particles and the Earth's neutral oxygen and nitrogen atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The atoms are destroyed and the particles are absorbed by the atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: The atoms are excited and emit photons, producing the northern and southern lights

options.label: C
options.text: The atoms are unaffected and the particles pass through the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: The atoms are repelled by the particles and sent back to the Sun

title: Inside your computer - Bettina Bair

multiple-choice.question: What is the basic input/output subsystem responsible for in a computer?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a way for the computer to interact with its environment.

options.label: B
options.text: It generates an interrupt to the CPU.

options.label: C
options.text: It decides which programs to run.

options.label: D
options.text: It fetches instructions from memory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main job of the CPU in a computer?

options.label: A
options.text: To fetch instructions from memory and execute them.

options.label: B
options.text: To store data in memory.

options.label: C
options.text: To generate interrupts to the basic input/output subsystem.

options.label: D
options.text: To compile programs.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to human-readable programming languages like Java, C++, or Python when they are compiled?

options.label: A
options.text: They are made larger and contain more unnecessary information.

options.label: B
options.text: They are stored in memory as bits of ones and zeros.

options.label: C
options.text: They are compiled and made smaller, and stored in memory as bits of ones and zeros.

options.label: D
options.text: They are deleted from the computer.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the CPU ask memory for the monitor program when the mouse is clicked?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the CPU needs to show the video associated with the button.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the CPU needs to find out what the button is.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the CPU needs to execute the instructions for the mouse program.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the CPU needs to store the data from the mouse click.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of clicking a mouse button on a computer?

options.label: A
options.text: The CPU executes a single instruction to move the mouse cursor.

options.label: B
options.text: The CPU fetches and executes billions of instructions a second.

options.label: C
options.text: The CPU visits all of the critical components of the computer's architecture, including peripherals, the basic input/output system, the CPU, programs, and memory.

options.label: D
options.text: The CPU generates an interrupt to the basic input/output subsystem.

title: If superpowers were real: Invisibility - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: If you were invisible, what would be a problem you would face while moving around undetected by other people?

options.label: A
options.text: You would have to wear clothes to stay warm.

options.label: B
options.text: You would have to carry your wallet and keys to stay organized.

options.label: C
options.text: You would have to be totally naked and can't carry anything.

options.label: D
options.text: You would have to wear perfume to stay alert.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to an invisible person if they were to get scolding hot coffee spilled on them?

options.label: A
options.text: They would become visible again.

options.label: B
options.text: They would feel the pain but remain invisible.

options.label: C
options.text: They would become visible because of the coffee.

options.label: D
options.text: They would not feel the pain because they are invisible.

multiple-choice.question: What would be a problem for an invisible person if everyone in the world was permanently invisible?

options.label: A
options.text: They would have to find a new way to communicate.

options.label: B
options.text: They would have to find a new way to receive medical treatment.

options.label: C
options.text: They would have to find a new way to get food.

options.label: D
options.text: They would have to find a new way to sleep.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't an invisible person see?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their eyes are closed.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not looking at anything.

options.label: C
options.text: Because light cannot bounce off them for their eyes to see.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are blind.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to an invisible person if they had an illness or an infection?

options.label: A
options.text: The doctor would be able to diagnose them easily.

options.label: B
options.text: The doctor would have to rely on their intuition to diagnose them.

options.label: C
options.text: The doctor would not be able to diagnose them because they cannot see the symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The doctor would not be able to treat them because they are invisible.

options.label: B
options.text: Energy

options.label: C
options.text: Velocity

options.label: D

options.text: Because air is too dense

options.label: B
options.text: Because air has a lot of free space for particles to move past one another

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans are too heavy

options.label: D

options.text: The bends

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Because the air would be too cold

options.label: B

title: If superpowers were real: Immortality - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: How might the passage of time feel differently to a 10-year-old boy compared to a 40-year-old mother?

options.label: A
options.text: The 10-year-old boy would feel like he's aging much faster than the 40-year-old mother.

options.label: B
options.text: The 10-year-old boy would feel like he's aging at the same rate as the 40-year-old mother.

options.label: C
options.text: The 10-year-old boy would feel like he's aging much slower than the 40-year-old mother.

options.label: D
options.text: The 10-year-old boy would feel like he's aging at a different rate than the 40-year-old mother.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential problem with immortality, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Immortality would make everyone look the same.

options.label: B
options.text: Immortality would make everyone look younger.

options.label: C
options.text: Immortality would lead to loneliness and sadness due to outliving loved ones.

options.label: D
options.text: Immortality would make everyone forget their past.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to the average height of humans over a million years if women find taller men more attractive?

options.label: A
options.text: The average height would remain the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The average height would decrease.

options.label: C
options.text: The average height would increase.

options.label: D
options.text: The average height would fluctuate.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential problem with immortality in terms of physical appearance?

options.label: A
options.text: Immortality would make everyone look more attractive.

options.label: B
options.text: Immortality would lead to a loss of body hair.

options.label: C
options.text: Immortality would result in a buildup of scars and damage over time.

options.label: D
